text: Bottle with commonmac during March madness. Dark reddish copper with thick white head and good lacing. Really good strong pumpkin spice aroma with underlying alcohol. Taste is heavy in spice , especially nutmeg and sugar. Sweet and sticky. Has good body, almost like it had real pumpkin in it. Alcohol presence heavier than most pumpkin ales. Alcohol could have been hidden better, and a bit of off balance, but very good. Glad I took a schlaflyer on this one. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

12oz bottle shared by commonshawn and purchased by Qponnagy. Pours an eye-pleasing copper/well-lit amber with a quarter finger eggshell white head. Aroma of pumpkin pie spices potent enough to fill the nose from afar. Cinnamon and nutmeg seem to be at the forefront. Taste struggles to fulfill the expectations brought about by the aroma but the pumpkin spices are still prevalent. Slightly thin mouthfeel but the alcohol presence makes you take notice. There is a malty/bready quality playing a role as well. Finish does make you think youve just eaten a piece of pumpkin pie soaked in alcohol. Probably exactly what Schlafly was attempting to execute. For people who enjoy this style, I think this should be a must try.
Pours a reddish chestnut brown with aroma of nutmeg, cinnamon, and pumpkin. Pumpkin flavor with nutmeg, cinnamon, and clove spicey flavor. Very nice.
12 oz. bottle. Pour was maroon/brown, foamy off white head. Aroma was pumpkin spice, nutmeg, clove. Taste was sweet, pumpkin flavor, pumpkin pie spices.

Pours dark amber color, clear, and effervescent with a very small head. Smells full of nutmeg, pumpkin, malty, cinnamon. The flavor starts out with the pumpkin, nutmeg, and some light maltiness followed by an aftertaste of pumpkin pie with just a little bitterness of alcohol.

Bottle from Js. Pours a clear copper with a half finger of foam that dissipates quickly. Big cinnamon and nutmeg notes. A bit Belgian in flavor and aromas. Light on the palate with some clove and Belgian yeast notes. Hides the abv well.

Thanks Steve.
This was poured into a becher pint glass.
The appearance was a dark amber/red/brown color with a mild concave lacing on the sides. No head. Carbonation could be seen rising.
The aroma balances absolutely awesome between the pumpkin sweet flesh to the spices of allspice, ginger and cinnamon.
The flavor, once again, has an incredible balance between the malts and the spices. Some pie crust, but subtle. Pumpkin flesh aftertaste. No finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a great sessionability. Spices just end up blending so well that they dont even emit any harshness on my tongue.
Overall, damn nice pumpkin ale that I would love to have again.
Nice thin white head accompanied by a mild spiced aroma. Flavor is herbs, spices, and mild pumpkin Body is medium/creamy with a carbonated kick.

Bottle. Pours a murky amber orange with a quickly fading light beige bubbly head. Aroma is of pumpkin, ginger, clove. Taste is of pumpkin, cinnamon, ginger, clove, lemon, nutmeg. Oily mouthfeel, soft to medium carbonation.

Had this from a bottle at the Boathouse in Forest Park, St Louis. Good pumpkin and spice flavors but still tastes like beer and with 8% alcohol it packs a punch!

F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a clear copper. Has a pumpkin, cinnamon, and nutmeg aroma. A strong pumpkin, nutmeg, and light malt taste that make it balanced and not overly sweet. A medium body and balanced pumpkin ale.

12 oz bottle. Copper color with a negligible white head. Visible carbonation. Aromas of clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, melted butter, and canned pumpkin. Heavy on the fall spices, vanilla, and processed pumpkin. A bit of alcohol in the finish but smooth and easy drinking.

Bottle into glass. Ugly looking dirty brown w no head. Mild pumpkin pie aroma and stronger pumpkin spice taste I am not a huge fan of gimmick beer but it is drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Pi. Beautiful clear deep amber pour with offwhite head -- good retention and lacing. Initial take on aroma was "whoa urinal cake" but its not their fault that people want to piss on pumpkin pie. Pumpkin spice thats heavier on vanilla and clove than on cinnamon. Nicely sweet, backed by light bitterness. Medium body, average carbonation, slick texture. Really pleasant to drink. Its been a long time since Ive enjoyed a pumpkin beer this much. Nicely done.

bottle @ Florence Freedom game --- Clear medium dark amber, beige head that sinks to a full rim, sheets of lace. Taste is malt that is quickly surpassed by pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon, and maybe a little clove. Strong on the pumpkin pie, and little remedy for the sweet. Fair to middlin.

Bought a 6 pack of bottles at Krogers grocery store in Midlothian Virgina on 8/26/16. Bottle date states 7/21/16! WHY SO EARLY??? Fall isnt till next month! Ridiculous that this style of beer is brewed this early! JULY? Who wants a pumpkin beer in july or august? But I had to try it because of the hype behind this beer! Poured a beautiful dark amber and smelled of spices right from the pouring. Smooth Smooth mouthfeel with generous amount of nutmeg and cinnamon! Great balance between the malt and spices. They say its brewed with pumpkin and butternut squash but it is absoultely DELICIOUS!! Would love to have this beer late october with the falling tempertures! (not now when it is in the 90s!) Enjoy the rest of the summer and THE FALL!!

12oz bottle 12/9/15 (Crown Plaza-STL)-Pours amber with a white heqad. Aroma of pumpkin, spices, and pumpkin pie. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and one of the better pumpkin beers.

This is my favorite fall seasonal beer and favorite pumpkin beer. Its the tastes are balanced with hints of whip cream and squash. The pumpkin flavor is strong with this one. It tastes like a pumpkin pie. Definitely one of their best beers.
Bottle gift from Pop. Probably the best pumpkin I have ever had. Not overbearing, but still pumpkin, spice, nutmeg etc. Blended well with a splash of vanilla. Very good.

Bottle, thanks Wolff. 

Amber with a white head. A lot of "pepparkaka" both in the aroma and taste. Cinnamon, light malt, some fruit and hints of caramel. I am not a fan of "Pumpkin beers" but this was a decent one.
Its a really good Pumpkin Ale. Pumpkin beers are usually better as Stouts or Porters, but this aint bad.
Decent for a autumnal ale. Flavorful, nice appearance and good aroma. I wouldnt drink it year round but it ushers in the season nicely.

Draft at the Pour House in Westmont, NJ. 

Pours a hazy and very dark golden orange color thats almost brown with dark burnt orange edges and a one finger beige head that quickly settles into a thin ring. Steaks of lace left behind. 

Sweet pumpkin pie aroma with a decent balance of pumpkin purée and autumnal spices. Pumpkin seed, pie filling, nutmeg and vanilla along with cinnamon and brown sugar. Subtle vegetal quality but more dessert like than earthy. 

Medium body with a strong zesty autumnal spice presence that dominates up frot lingering over the sweet malts before a sweet pumpkin pie/dessert presence shows up in the finish. Peppery with ginger, clove and cinnamon followed by caramel malt, pumpkin purée, vanilla and nutmeg. Interesting how the flavor profile changes mid palate. Still tons of spice but more dessert like in the finish. Only a subtle vegetal presnce but it makes it a bit more organic tasting than a pure dessert beer. Nice balance of both approaches to the style. Decently balanced but could be a touch sweeter.

Served in snifter at Schlafly Bottleworks, dark copper with good sized white head. Pumpkin aroma, flavor has good balance of nutmeg and cloves. Finish becomes less pleasant the more you drink this, unless you enjoy funk at the tail end. Solid pumpkin offering, but not quite at the top of my list in that category.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a great clear reddish amber color with a small white head. The aroma is full pumpkin and spices. The flavor is outstanding. This nay be my favorite pumpkin ale.
Typical pumpkin ale with some clove and other spices. Some vegetable matter. Pours orange. Sweet finish with a slightly syrupy consistency. Not my thing. Sample pour at whole foods.

12 oz. bottle poured to a Czech-pils glass at Lunar Brewing Co., displaying a hazed, amber color, with a frothy layer of tan head foam that diminished gradually to a persistent ring & light film, leaving spots & patches of lacing on the glass. The aroma was a pleasant scent of mild pumpkin, a balanced blend of pie spices, and a variety of hints as earthiness, dried fruit as currant, a little cherry tanginess, and a touch of apple. Medium bodied with good carbonation, the taste resembled the nose, plus some amped cinnamon stick, modest, earthy bitterness, and a bit of malty creaminess to the mouthfeel. Gradually becoming a benchmark, seasonal pumpkin beer for me.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2015 Really nice. On tap at blend. Cardamom. Coffee ?? Best of 4 in a flight of public.

Humbled in 2015 tasting and did not advance through a tough heat.   I still really liked it.   5th of 13, round 1b.
Deep amber with a cream head. Nose is heavy pumpkin, spice, nutmeg and pie. Smooth palate, pumpkin spice, nutmeg, clove, great finish.

10/07/2015: On the sweet and strong side; dangerously drinkable. Underlying caramelized pumpkin is nice with just a bit of cinammon and clove spice, perhaps a bit of nutmeg as well. Quite good which is a surprise to me since I dont typically care for Schafly beers... Draught at Village Pizza in Newtown, Ohio.
Pours dark amber. Aroma of clove and cinnamon, like mulled wine or cider. Taste is moderately sweet, spicy, malty, with a whisper of hops and alcohol. Mouthfeel is strong and pleasant.

Robe cuivrée, mousse moyennement. 
Saveurs rondes de canelle, citrouille, clou de girofle, noix de muscade et sucre candy. Le final est sur une note de malt toasté. Moyennement longue en bouche.
Texture légèrement crémeuse.
Trop épicée à mon goût, mais une bonne bière.

12 ounce bottle. Copper color with a large creamy taupe head. Wonderful pumpkin aroma has notes of cinnamon, mace and nutmeg. Rich, creamy toasted malt flavor with all right spices. Cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, ginger and more. There is a touch of brown sugar as well. Slightly bittersweet in the finish. This ranks right up their with the best pumpkin ales I have tasted. A pleasant surprise.

Pours a hazy copper color with a white head. Aromas of pumpkin nutmeg and a little cinnamon. Taste the same with some malty sweetness. Nice lacing in the glass. Medium palate. Really nice ale. Little alcohol but nut to much. Very nice complex flavor.
Tap...amber brown pour with a fresh pumpkin pie nose. Balanced and complex without being overdone. Nice.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle, bottled on August 8, 2015, poured into a glass. Dark Amber with medium beige head.  Aroma is sweet pumpkin, medium body, little carbonation, and good small-bubble lacing.  Taste is pumpkin, nutmeg, and some clove.

Aroma: pumpkin pie spice, caramel, 
Appearance: clear amber, off-white head
Taste: medium sweetness, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg
Palate: medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Delicious

Pours deep copper with medium beige head that quickly dissipates, leaving slight skim.
Excellent aroma of pumpkin and pie spices. Clove, cinnamon and nutmeg are all there in the glass, but not so much that they overwhelm the baked pumpkin and butternut squash flavors. Thats augmented by hints of peach, caramel and vanilla.
Medium body, restrained carbonation, sweetish without being cloying and a finish that is true to the rest of the glass.
A good start to the season: Schlafly has made a contender for the best American pumpkin beer, and a model for how to keep a brew balanced while hitting a specific flavor profile.

Im not the type of person who likes pumpkin beers. In fact, I could do entirely without the autumn pumpkin release trend. Schlafly Pumpkin Ale was a game-changer. This stuff is like liquid pumpkin pie. Except its better than some pumpkin pies Ive tried. The nutmeg, clove, and cinnamon are used perfectly. The pumpkin doesnt taste like it came from a pumpkin candle for once and the rich, creamy malt isnt buried by all the other flavors. I want this beer on my Thanksgiving table.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2015 Dark, sweet, gets better with each drink. The flavor is definately there. Would prob rate higher but this beer is not my style. One is plenty for me but nice effort here by schlafly.

Draft/Fest.

A- Pumpkin, squash, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, spices, caramel, bready, pie, vanilla.

A- Copper red color, clear liquid, off white head.

T- Pumpkin pie, spice.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- This is as good of a pumpkin beer as you can find. Nothing artificial about this at all. Tastes like a delicious pumpkin pie and tons of spice flavors going on.
Bottled. Lots of cinnamon all spice etc fl following a clear orange brown pour white head. Graham crackers and pumpkins. Very nice.

Nice mixed aroma of spices, caramel, candy corn, and cinnamon. Nice deep orange color with a tan head. Wow, nice creamy malt up front. Nice mix of spiciness and sweet. Flavors taste authentic, not fake. Bitterness fades in nicely with some heat from the spiciness. Creamy mourthfell. Best pumpkin beer Ive ever had by far.

Bottle. Dark Amber orange thats clearish. Vanilla, all spice, cinnamon, spruce, and Graham cracker in the aroma. Flavor is the same, thin, but vanilla, cinnamon, clove and crackers. Lighting slick body.
Bottled on July 29th, 9 days ago. Maybe my favorite pumpkin beer. Pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla. I know its early August, but this beer makes me yearn for fall.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2015 Bottle poured into a tulip glass..amber/rusty pour with a fluffy off white head..aroma of pumpkin,carrot cake,nutmeg,cinnamon...tastes of pumpkin,carrot cake,cinnamon,nutmeg,ginger..not a big fan of pumpkin beers but this is best one by far..excellent.

On tap half pint at Bradley's Food and Beverage in Bethesda, MD. 

Clear, reddish brown with a khaki head and good lacing. 

Aroma of pumpkin pie with all the usual spices, caramel and pumpkin fruit. 

Taste of a delicious pumpkin pie with an abundance of pumpkin fruit blended nicely with all the usual pie spices. I'm detecting a little caramel and peach as well. 

Medium body and medium/high carbonization. 

An excellent "liquid pumpkin pie."

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes. Tasted some time near the fall of 2012 from a capped 12oz bottle. Pours deep, dark orange with an average tan head that leaves thin lace. The nose is just like a spiced pumpkin pie, plenty of cinnamon, nutmeg, and baked pumpkin. The flavor is has a lot of additional caramel malt that is a bit sweeter than I would like, but tastes like a pumpkin pie otherwise with some bitterness from the baking spices. The body is medium with average carbonation and a long spiced pumpkin finish.

12oz bottle pours dark clear ruby red with a finger of foam. Nose is all spice, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove and pumpkin pie with a hint of fruity malt. Palate is more malt forward with some semi-sweet and bitter medicinal cherry fruit notes coupled with heavy handed "pumpkin" spice. A hint of vegetal gourd. Finish is bitter thick malty fruit sweetness, spices galore. Doesnt do anything new or anything exceptional in the pumpkin beer category. Nose is the best part.

Sampled @ Exclusive S&G Tasting: Special guest 77ships. APPEARANCE: clear darker blond beer, small unstable off white head.
NOSE: gingerbread, peppercake, cinnemon, pepper in general.
TASTE: about the same uni dimensional thing.
Best pumpkin beer Ive ever had around these parts. Classic pumpkin pie spices and warm, round finish. YUM
One of the better pumpkin ales Ive tried. Spices. Smooth. I dont want a lot of it, but good.

Appearance is deep brown with minimal off white foam cap. Aroma is an intense pumpkin pie spicing of allspice, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Vanilla also stands out. Taste is a rich caramel malt with vanilla, allspice, nutmeg, cinnamon, and ginger. Mouthfeel is moderate with a slight creaminess and low carbonation. Finishes with a lingering spice flavor of nutmeg and cinnamon.

On tap at ribco, pours a clear dark reddish brown with a very thin off white head, aroma had a nice amount of cinnamon mixed in with pumpkin spice and vanilla, flavor had a good amount of spice but its not overdone, really nice stuff.

Pours orange with a creamy off-white head. Pumpkin pie aroma. The flavor is very sweet with pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla, and allspice. The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Light to medium body with a high level of carbonation. Very tasty, one of the better pumpkin beers I have had this year.

Enjoyed at Northdown Tap in Chicago, IL while shooting darts with some friends. I didnt realize that Schlafly started distributing in Chicago, and now I am thrilled. Never had the chance to get this one during the fall in St Louis, really happy to have had this and it lives up to the hype. Fantastic pumpkin ale, rich in nutmeg and cinnamon with a great sweetness and finish. I will have this again.
Without a doubt the best pumkin ale I have ever had. The spice scents hit you even while you pour and gives you a punch when you drink.

355 ml. bottle split by 3 @ Exclusive S&G Tasting: Special guest 77ships. Thanks to Mathieu87 & PriorL. Dark amber, no head. Nose is pure yam & pumpkin pie nose, thick spices, cinnamon, nutmeg, sweet spices. Taste is pure yam pie, some pumpkin pie, baked butternut squash, sweet, brown sugar, nutmeg, cinnamon, sweet malt. Solid body. Very nice, very good.
Dark amber no head; slightly spicy aroma; Flava is sweet hints of cinnamon spice; feels medium silky; finishes sweet malty

I was starting to give up on pumpkin beers. Autumn would hit, I'd say I can't wait for them to start coming out, then they'd keep disappointing me. This one is more spice than pumpkin. Almost too much like a pie, which is awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep, dark amber/cherry wood color. Decent carbonation and head retention for a pumpkin. Have been somewhat underwhelmed by Schlafly offerings, so was looking forward to sampling this much-heralded fall seasonal. Aromas of cinnamon, apple pie crust, rice pudding, clove. This honestly reminds me more of apple pie than pumpkin pie. A bit misleading, but I dont mind since it is quite tasty. Tastes like cinnamon apple sauce, baked apples (think...cobbler dessert), cinnamon stick and to a lesser extent nutmeg, clove and gourd. Fantastic dessert beer with a nice spiced, tingly aftertaste.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Deep reddish brown brew with small head. Fince aroma of pumpkin spice, maybe some squash and pumpkin itself. Taste is full bodied, somewhat sweet at the start with a restrained spie finish (restrained is good, IMO.) Very rich and full bodied. A little boozey but otherwise a real treat.

Bottle from City Swiggers, New York, NY. A dark orange/amber coloured pour with a thin off white head on top. Pumpkin, spice, nutmeg, cinammon aroma. Tastes similar, pumpkin, spice, nutmeg, cinnamon. A rich tasting pumpkin number, I really enjoyed this one.

This is a very cinnamon-centric take on the style. It is actually better than most Schlafly beers but thats honestly not saying much. It is a perfectly clear brownish orange color w/ a small white head. It smells more like apple pie than pumpkin pie to me as there is a very strong apple aroma to go along w/ the cinnamon--nor sure what cases that but I have noticed it in other spiced beers as well. This is a pretty full bodied beer and somewhat creamy w/ mild carbonation. The flavor is light and only offers some earthy hops to go along w/ the spice. Overall, not a bad take on the style even though the heavy apple note is a little wierd.

You can taste both the pumpkin and butternut squash without one overpowering the other too much. Was very surprised to find out it was a 8%, so it should keep for over 6 months if you feel like drinking this early next year.

On draft at Justin's Cafe in Navy Yard, DC. Dark amber and thick, nice white head. Aroma of pumpkin pie. Malt, nutmeg, cinnamon, pumpkin, light dough, light bitterness and crisp taste. I'm usually not a pumpkin fan but this one is really good. Definitely worth it.
Orange/copper pour with watery white head and lace. Aroma is pumpkin pie spices and pumpkin. Flavor mirrors aroma with no noticeable hop presence. A tad thin and watery to me but still solid

The aroma was interesting and inviting. The appearance of the beer was as expected, but on the good side of average. The taste its self had its different notes that were hit on the nose. The palate was surprising, a pumpkin beer that tasted like pumpkin pie, that still had the good bitter notes to keep it from being a desert.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with red streaks in the light with a small light khaki head, some lacing. Smells of warm pumpkin pie spices. Well balanced taste of cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, brown sugar, pumpkin, malts, and butternut squash. Spices and medium texture up front with yummy pie middle that finishes semi - dry. Excellent pumpkin ale.

Pours a dark amber with a thick off white head that dissipates quickly and leaves almost no lacing in the glass. Aroma is sweet with nutmeg spices. Taste is sweet on the back end with a ton of pumpkin spices, nutmeg and cinnamon. A little bitter at first but a nice pumpkin flavor. Finally Schlafly does something right.
Looks like a glass of dark honey with a white/orange head. A little carbonation. Aroma is slight pumpkin and nutmeg. Flavor is very pumpkiney with nutmeg and alcohol. Decent brew!

Pours amber and fairly clear. Aroma smells like fall and is packed with pumpkin, nutmeg, vanilla, spices. Taste follows suit and is just like a fresh baked pumpkin pie. Medium body, creamy, and hides the alcohol well. Very tasty, almost like having a dessert in liquid form. Ive had many pumpkin beers in my past and wasnt a fan, but this and Pumking are two of the better ones out there.
Amazing seasonal beer brewed by Schlafly and St. Louis Brewing Company. Perfect combo of pumpkin, cinnamon, and nutmug. Has a distinctive spice to it. Overall tasty beer.

Sampled at MNF at eaglefan538s house. I hate these things, so Im just going to rate it down the middle to be fair. Its like an iced pumpkin cookie. I guess its ok for a pumpkin beer. Its creamy, smooth and sickly sweet. *shrug*

Smells just like a pumpkin pie. Wonderful amber color with a smallish off white head. The taste is where it falls off for me. For the most part it tastes like a pumpkin pie, but has a fakeness to the aftertaste that resembles plastic. Alcohol is not very well hidden; I was surprised that it is only 8%. I want to like this beer so much, but the aftertaste just ruins it for me. No way should it be a 97.

Really nice pumpkin pie beer. Reddish orange appearance. Well spiced. Canned pumpkin throughout. A little booze. Not to sweet. Maybe a little sour in the finish. Im trying a few of these this year, and so far the leader for me is AleWerks, but this one is up there.

Bottle pour, no head or lacing, Nice nutmeg/pumpkin sweet aroma. Amber color and cloudy. Smooth mid bodied flavored beer.  Spices are not overwhelming.  Low carbonation. Enjoyable fall beer, the wife throws a shot of whipped vodka in to it for the full pumpkin pie with whipped cream affect.
Dark amber, nice white head. Aroma of pumpkin pie with whip cream, wow! Malt, nutmeg, cinnamon, pumpkin, light dough, light bitterness and crisp taste. Great Punkin beer

Been putting this one off for a long time. I hate this kind of beer perversion, but a kid at work recommended and what is beer for but to increase social interaction. So I tried and loved it. Tastes like a liquid pumpkin pie with whipped cream. Perfect that they made this a "big" beer with 8% ABV. After I tried one, I bought a 12 pack to bring to Thanksgiving dinner.

"Definitely in the upper tier of pumpkin ales (though not quite the best - Good Gourd, Elysian Great Pumpkin, Night Owl, and Almanac Pumpkin Barleywine are the top 4). Sneaky 8% only shows in the body, which is robust and super super smooth. Malty, with a good sweet pumpkin flavor and mild to moderate use of spices. Finishes rich and warm. "

Six pack from Crown Liquor. Pours a light amber with an inch of off-white head with good retention. Nice aroma of cinnamon, squash, and spices. Tastes like a slice of pumpkin pie: allspice, nutmeg, veggie, subtle caramel, metal, even a doughy element that reminds me of pie crust. Vanilla in the finish (whipped cream on top)! Medium carbonation and body. Surely, a great representation of the style and one of my favorites since DFH's Punkin Ale. Excellent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

4 oz draft pour at ChurchKey. Clear amber with off-white head. Aromas of cinnamon, pumpkin, graham cracker. Tastes of pumpkin, cinnamon, spices, vegetable. Medium body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation. One of the better pumpkin ales out there.

Bottled. Pours orange in color with an orange/beige head, very nice head, and real nice lacing, Aroma is big pumpkin, cinnamon, sugar, nutmeg. Aroma is excellent. Flavor is pumpkin with the kind of heat youd expect from a beer this strong. Very nice mouthfeel as well.

Bottled July 23, 2014.
Glass: Firestone Walker reserve tulip.
Appearance: Clear copper reddish with a quickly dissipating light tan head.
Aroma: Clove, cinnamon, nutmeg and apples come to mind. It reminds me more of an apple pie than a pumpkin pie. Aroma is moderate in strength and pleasant.
Taste: The flavor is very reminiscent of cinnamon covered apple sauce. Not that its a bad thing at all, but this doesnt remind me of pumpkins.
Palate: Medium bodied mildly carbonated.
Overall: Blind taste I would call this an apple sauce beer. Open eyed I still say the same. This isnt a pumpkin beer, but its enjoyable.
One of the best Pumpkin Ale beers Ive tasted amongst the five different ones that Ive had
Bottle shared. Pours a transparent amber with a ring of off white head. Aroma of pumpkin and nutmeg. Tons of nutmeg and spices on the taste.
Aroma of pumpkin, clove, nutmeg, taste is pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, easy on the palate, smooth finish, a pumpkin ale that was done right!
On draft at schlafly tap room. Loads of pumpkin on aroma and taste. A great fall beer. I was surprised
Ridiculous aroma... Smells like pumpkin pie and reminds me of Thanksgiving. One of my favorite fall beers. Nice amber color, good rich body but clean finish. Great beer but not meant to be cellared.

[Bottle] Pours orange in color with a large white head. Nose is of pumkin pie spices and caramel malts. Tastes of ginger, cloves, nutmeg and pumpkin. Creamy mouthfeel. Lingering sweet and mulled spice finish. Nice! Tasting notes from 2012.

Bottle shared at a tasting Mastikim. Pours orange deep with a small head, aroma of Pumpkin, cinnamon, Pumpkin cake and carrot, flavor of Pumpkin and Pumpkin cake, carrot, allspice and cinnamon, medium bodied.
bottle - Pours light red/amber with a very small head. It has a heavy spice aroma with cinnamon and nutmeg the most obvious to me. Its sweet, spicy, medium bodied, and pretty good.
A reddish orange beer with hardly any head. The aroma is pumpkin and lots of cinnamon. The flavor is like dough and pumpkin pie.

Very pumpkiny! Slightly hazy copper orange in color. Solid aroma of pumpkin pie with a hint of caramel. Spicy notes upfront with clean malt and pumpkin flavor. Followed by a nice herbal bitterness. Overall im not big on pumpkin ales but this one is nice. Hat tip to BarZigKin for sharing.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Mastikim. Thanks zvikar. Amber. Aroma of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg and honey cookies notes. Pretty sweet flavor with pumpkin, honey and spices. Medium-bodied.

Pours dark orange with light brown and amber. The aroma is all pumpkin pie, brown sugar, and light cinnamon. The taste follows suit but, it's more mellow than most pumpkin beers. This one is a smooth pumpkin beer. Even though it's on the desert side, it's not too much in any way. Rich, malty, tasty and very drinkable. Not bad.
Drank from bottle. A good pumpkin beer but the smell and taste of cinnamon is a little overwhelming. Everything else about this beer is done really well. Good desert beer

bottled 16AUG11

A: Pours a dark copper ale with a single finger of tan foam which falls quickly to a sheet of the same. Spotty lacing.

S: Cinnamon and nutmeg up front with some sweet graham crust smells. Light pumpkin meat.

T: Lots of squash flavor, some sweet cheery like flavor with the spices. 

M: Medium on thin body with soft carbonation leaving a slightly wet finish. 

O: this is quite pumpkin foward. I cant recall a beer I have had previously with so much pumpkin/vegetable flavor. I like how the spices were played here, would almost like to throw a dollop of whipped cream in here.

Serving type: bottle

09-18-2011

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2014 Bottle acquired through a trade with Strykzone, Thanks Dave! -- Pours a nice ruddy brown with just a bit of head. The aroma is amazing, it smells just like my grandmas homemade pumpkin pie tastes! The flavor follows the nose almost identically although the flavor leaves me a little wanting, wish it was a little fuller. Body is pleasant. Overall I would very much like to drink this straight through fall and winter. I really like this beer.

12oz bottle poured into a tulip.
Hazy deep amber color with nice red reddish hues and decent off white head.
Strong pumpkin nose, with caramel, cinnamon, cardamom, and chai-like aromas.
Sweet squash, caramel, heavy spice, lo bitterness and decent maltiness.
Full body, rich, a bit too sweet, but overall interesting.
Bottle. Pours dark amber medium white head. Strong pumpkin aroma, cinnamon, nutmeg, and other spices. Medium sweet taste. Medium-full body, average body, spice finish. Overall all solid pumpkin ale.

Bottle, courtesy of olr1984  thanks! Pours a deep copper/light amber color with an ample beige head. At first sniff, the nose has a greater depth than many of the spiced pumpkin ales. Heavy on the pumpkin, a light and airy crust sensation, and nutmeg with light cinnamon. Sensational! Taste is good pumpkin flavor, but gets a little heavy-handed with the spices. Nutmeg, cinnamon, and cardamom. Finish is quite spicy. I could sniff this all night long, but Im staring at my glass wishing it would taste just half as delicious as the aroma.
Reddish bronze with some floaties. Creamy resilient head. This is an insane pumpkin nose. Taste is very herbal with thyme and basil. Obvious mix of pumpkin and chord with sugary sweetness.

Although I wish I had a stout or porter version of this, the Schafly Pumpkin Ale is probably the best genuine pumpkin ale Ive tried yet. While the others claim to be pumpkin ales and impart notes of only clove, nutmeg, and allspice, this one is similar to pumpkin pie in a glass. True pumpkin flavor prevails and makes this a smooth, refreshing drink.

2012 vintage

Pours minimal carbonation, hazy dark amber

Draft. Deep amber body with a fizzy, off-white head. The aroma is spicy with notes of nutmeg, cinnamon and all spice. All that alongside meaty pumpkin. And some toasted grain. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. Tastes are similar to the aroma: spice and pumpkin  and some peppery alcohol notes in the finish. This is like drinking a rich pumpkin pie made with lots of cream. The 8% alcohol shows up in the finish. Couldnt drink a lot of this because of the sweetness. Close to being cloying.

12 oz bottle. I find very few flaws in this beer for the style. Its really half pumpkin pie, half malty strong ale with great balance all-around and just enough of every ingredient. The nose consists of blended spices, with nutmeg and cinnamon being the most prominent, pumpkin pie, mixed, mellow herbs, and rich, malty cereal grains. A decent pour as well, with a finger and half of bubbling off-white head, sticky retention, and a semi-translucent deep amber color. The palate is unexpectedly strong (until I read the abv), especially for a spiced ale like this, though still creamy, rich and malty, with just enough hops to balance things nicely. Flavors start off with sweet fruits and buttery pumpkin, leading to more mixed grain malt and spices similar to the aroma. Herbal notes stand out a bit more through the sweet and spicy finish. Overall, and considering that pumpkin ales are usually not my thing, I think Schlafly did a pretty darn good job constructing this one.

Very sweet finish. Full body with syrupy mouthfeel and low carbonation. Cloying, syrupy, alcoholic, phenolic. Something went wrong here. Wasted 12$ on this drain-pour of a 6-pack.

Draft.  Pour is a deep orange/ copper with a small white ring of foam. Aroma is loaded with pumpkin pie spice, caramel malt, and a light herbal note.  Flavor is also full of deep pumpkin pie spice, sweet caramel malt, and notes of spicy clove.  This is deep and rich.  Really pretty tasty.

Bottle; Pour is fairly clear dark golden amber with a nice, foamy white head in this glass. It retains on the average side, with light, spotty lacing present as well. The nose is heavy on the spices; clove, cinnamon, and nutmeg are present. The flavor profile presents the aforementioned spices up front, coupled with some sweetness from the malt profile - while the body rounds out fairly negatively for me, actually. I suppose the squash adds a touch of interest. This is a nice holiday ale, but it didnt quite do it for me as a pumpkin in general.

Aroma of pumpkin pie, cinnamon and whipped cream. Appearance is red/orange with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with some interesting rye notes; the alcohol is impeccably hidden. Palate is bubbly. Tasty, tasty stuff.

Thanks to oline on BA for this tick.  12oz bottle.  Mostly clear deep reddish-amber in color with a nice lasting off-white head.  The aroma has pumpkin spices - cinnamon and nutmeg - along with...cherry?  Lots of cherry in there to go with a touch of pumpkin.  The flavor has caramel and toffee malt, both cherry and pumpkin notes, big cinnamon, nutmeg, and brown sugar.  Mild bitterness.  Medium-bodied with soft carbonation and a log finish.  An unconventional pumpkin ale, but you know what, I think it works.

When Damico told me this was a great pumpkin ale... somewhere between his 5.0 Pumking Ale and DFH Punkin...  I had some doubts.  But I was wrong.  This is a damn fine pumpkin ale.  One of the better ones.  Pours an orange brown color with a soapy white head.  Aroma of caramel, nutmeg, clove, with a nice warming cinnamon taste.  A nice gentle hop layer mixed in as well.  A sweet caramel taste with some flavorful cinnamon and nutmeg notes.  The bitters balance nicely.  Nice medium body.  Really good brew.

Bottle.  Pumpkin, cinnamon, clove, nutmeg aroma.  Dark amber color with moderately head.   Pumpkin malt initially followed by the spices:  nutmeg, clove, and cinnamon.  Nice spicy aftertaste.  Very good.
Bottle: pours dark brown with a thin head, aroma of spices, taste is malty, sweet, spiced.

Bottle. Poured clear orange brown color with an average creamy off-white head that was lasting with fair lacing. Medium to heavy pumpkin, cinnanon and nutmeg aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium pumpkin spice sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. This is a good beer.

Whole Foods, P St, DC sixer ($13): Pours a reddish color with a small, thin beige head. Aroma is pretty big. Cinnamon, nutmeg, sugary malts, are amongst the things I smell. This is a really malty ale. Maybe it is a little bit too sweet. Lots of spices are present throughout the taste. It has a kind of buttery mouthfeel. Basically, this is miles better than most pumpkin ales that exist and especially better than those I had most recently. Might be a little too much for some people though.

Bottle.

A - Burnt amber color with an average sized, foamy, bubbly, slightly stick, white head. Decent retention leaving a decent lacing.

S - Spices (primarily cinnamon and nutmeg) fight with slightly burnt caramel aroma for prominence. Mid to late smell there is plenty of sweet pumpkin pie aroma with some brown sugar. Pretty nice.

T - Very nice flavors. There is a good amount of actual pumpkin taste as opposed to pumpkin pie taste. That said the spices come on strong, especially on the finish. Clove is strongest but there is also cinnamon, nutmeg and all spice. Some buttery and brown sugar flavors mid sip. Some burnt caramel malt as well. Not overly sweet or spiced but a good mix.

M - Medium to light body with average carbonation. A touch too thin but not bad.

D - Great balance between sweet, spice and actual pumpkin flavor. Alcohol is very well hidden, no way Id guess it at 8%. Very enjoyable beer to drink and one I could drink a couple of in a night, despite the ABV.

Notes: Great pumpkin beer, probably the best one Ive had as of yet. Actual pumpkin flavor is wonderful compared to pumpkin meaning pumpkin pie. The mix between spices and brown sugar, buttery sweetness is great. Very enjoyable and Ill probably have to get some more. Recommended.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2016 12oz bottle, pours almost a dark amber brownish color with an off white head that disappears rather quickly. first aroma is of nutmeg and cinnamon and maybe canned pumpkin. the first taste is strong cinnamon and not much pumpkin. if you let this beer warm up you get the nutmeg and some pumpkin flavors but its still over shadowed by the cinnamon.

Pours a deep amber...very clear...with a medium tan head.  Aroma is slightly earthy and malty with all the traditonal spices...bit of caramel.  Flavor is caramely and spicy but not sweet or muddled...earthy...notable hoppiness.  Mouthfeel is lively and the finish is dry and more hoppy than most pumpkin ales Ive had.  Not quite up to the hype Ive heard.

clear dark amber with a small very white head... limited lacing, limited retention... this might be the first pumpkin ale where the beer actually smells like pumpkin, nutmeg is noticeable, cinnamon less so, spicing is fair, less than what i expected based on what ive heard/read about this beer... lively, medium bodied.. this is awesome.. this tastes like the filling of a pumpkin pie, its not quite complete because it doesnt incorporate the crust, but the flavor of the beer is amazing pumpkin pie filling flavor... becomes a bit tough to drink and the flavors fade quickly as the beer warms though...

It poured a copper color with an off-white head. The aroma was of some nice pumpkin and clove spice with nutmeg and cinnamon. The taste was mostly cinnamon and nutmeg on the palate, finish is very creamy.  A very good Pumpkin Ale.

12oz bottle from Picks poured into a lager glass. Pours a dark orange with about 1 finger of off-white head. Aroma of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla. Smells just like pumpkin pie. Taste is medium sweet. Tastes strongly of pumpkin, cinnamon and nutmeg. It tastes just like pumpkin pie in a bottle. Slightly aftertaste of vanilla. Medium bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish of cinnamon. Overall, its a very good beer. I couldnt drink more than a couple of these but it could easily take the place of any after dinner drink. Something worth seeking out.

I really liked this beer. A really nice pumpkin and spice flavor. Doesnt have the synthetic or cardboard flavors that many other fruit/spice beers have. A nice sweetness that compliments the spice well. Noticeably better than many of the other pumpkin beers Ive tried.

Ar: Deep notes of brown sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg - very pumpkin-pie-like.
Ap: Dark red-amber - small off-white head with good retention and fine bubbles - nice lacing.
T: Spicy up front, with lot of cinnamon and brown sugar - medium-sweet and some peppery and earthy notes mixing with a nice deep maltiness - finish is medium with clove flavor helping to dry things out.
P: Medium-full - medium-high carbonation - very rich mouthfeel.
O: Delicious! Substantial and warming fall beer that tastes like the season - great balance of spice, sweetness, and malt character, and good look to boot.
A solid pumpkin ale, this tastes just like pumpkin pie. If you looking for pumpkin pie in a bottle this is it, not over spiced and drinkable. Great color and smell.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Virginia Beach.  Pours brownish-orange with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma of pumpkin, faint cinnamon and nutmeg, and even more faint hops.  The flavor is really nice; sweet pumpkin and bold pumpkin pie spices are perfectly integrated so that none of the flavors tend to overwhelm.  Slight alcohol warmth on the finish but it is very welcome.  One of the best pumpkin beers I have tried.

Bottle at Churchkey. Orange amber pour with a small head. Nose and flavor both hold nice clove, pumpkin, light sweet malt, nutmeg, cinnamon, and a touch of earthiness. Crisp, easy drinking palate. Solid.

Schlafly Pumpkin Ale pours a very dark amber color.  The head is short but leaves some lacing.  The aroma is pumpkin spice and nutmeg.  I also detect an earthy smell in there.  The taste is malty sweet, but the spices tend to mellow out the sweetness.  This is medium-bodied and finishes nicely with a spicy punch.

The gap between really good pumpkin ales and the rest is pretty expansive.  This is a really good one.  It pours a dark amber with a fair white head.  The nose is spicy and fantastic--lots of cinnamon, nutmeg, apple pie, and pumpkin.  Many pumpkin ales have a really think mouth feel and depth of flavor, but not this one.  Pumpkin pie spices dominate.  This is a really spicy pumpkin ale and I dig it.  The Weyerbacher Imperial Pumpkin ale has always been my go-to this time of year.  Ill need to drink this Schlafly offering alongside the Weyerbacher to pick one, because theyre both great.

Reddish brown with a cm of quickly fading tan head.  Aroma is sweet and a bit earthy with nutmeg and cinnamon.  Taste is mostly the same, and pretty well in line with all other pumpkin, with some heavier bits of spice astringency and some vanilla into the finish. $2/12oz

Reviewed from notes
Pours a slightly hazy brown with a slight off white head. Nose of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove. Taste was a lot of spice with a less pumpkin than expected. An very well put together pumpkin bear, not the greatest I have had but well above par.
Bottle. Pours slightly hazy brown with a small head. Smells of sour pumpkin and some spice. Taste... oh. This IS pumpkin pie. Pumpkin, spice, crust, and cream. Wow.
Bottle. Pours reddish amber. White head. Nose/taste of pumpkin, pie crust, nutmeg, all spice, clove and cinnamon. Lightish to medium body.

Small soapy tan head sits atop a clear orange/brown body. Minimal, spotty lacing . The nose is ripe with all those familiar pumpkin pie spices and some pumpkin flesh. First sip was unexpectedly sweet, though absolutely delicious! Notes of Graham cracker accompany an intense, yet drinkable pumpkin pie profile in the finish. Medium/short palate duration is made up for by a slightly slick, medium/full mouthfeel that gives this pumpkin brewhaha the oooomph it needs to be considered a great pumpkin ale, imo. I love pumpkin beers and this is now one of my faves. Thanks, Schlafly!

The best pumpkin Ive had to date. Pours an orangey brown with light head. Nose is all pumpkin and traditional pumpkin pie spices. Taste is more of the same with just enough hop bitterness creeping in at the end to ensure you know youre drinking beer.

Thanks to daknole.  Bottle pours orange with an off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove.  Flavor shows the same with additional hints of vanilla.  Damn tasty and overall one of the spicier pumpkin brews out there.
UPDATED: AUG 9, 2013 The best pumpkin ale in my opinion. Great balance between the pumpkin and spice. 8% is just right.

Poured into a snifter. Picked this up at Ricks a month or so back.

Color is a slightly-hazed orange color that is just a bit dark. A short white head with just a bit of lacing forms on the brew. The nose is fairly sweet with some nice pumpkin pie notes as well as a pretty good amount of pumpkin-pie spices.

The flavor is really nice with the sweet pumpkin, brown sugar, and spices really integrating together quite well. I couldnt believe that the alcohol was this high when I read it after drinking this one down a bit--its not detectable at all. Feel is nice and creamy. Medium body with good carbonation. Overall, one of the better pumpkin brews Ive come across and Im glad to try this one this season.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-19-2010

Orange pour, light head.  aroma is so strong on pumpkin, graham, pumpkin pie spice.  Flavor is, wow, an amazing creamy pumpkin pie! one of the spiciest and most pumpkin pie flavored beers I have tried.

Hazy mohagany/brown with orange and red highlights

smells of brown sugar and pumpkin spice with a bit of malt and alcohol. touch of cherry. no sign of hops, a little biscuit/graham cracker and sugar cookie

tastes a bit like liquid pumpkin pie. additional malt notes and some cherry. really low hop presence. A touch boozy. strange this beer almost reminds me of a bock because of the cherry notes and the malt.

head retention was awful, low carbontion. not impressed by that. a bit flat on the mouthfeel

drinkability is about average. a bit too much pumpkin spice without the carbonation and body to help it out.

Aroma:Pumpkin pie spice, nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla, ginger in the aroma.

Appearance:Orangish-red color.

Taste:Great pumpkin flavor, the pumpkin spices are well balanced.

Palate:Creamy, good carbonation.

Overall:This one is a good easy-drinking pumpkin ale. Ive had better, but Ive also had much worse.

The 12 oz bottle was courtesy of Strykzone.  Poured a very dark amber color with an off-white head that clung to the glass like glue. A strong nose of pumpkin pie aroma with nutmeg and cinnamon. Quite full bodied with as creamy smooth mouthfeel. The flavor is intense with lots of spices. The finish is very spicy with pumpkin backed with nutmeg, cinnamon, and cloves. Right up there with the very best of the pumpkin ales.
Pours a dark orange color.  Has some nice pumpkin pie flavors and aromas with some spicy apple aromas as well.  Very good pumpkin beer!

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
The nose is a light, earthy pumpkin with a bit of mace, leafy hops, cinnamon, and nutmeg.  Very nice.  It pours a deep amber color with a very frothy, light tan head.  Great head retention.  The flavor is malty and sweet with a heavy dose of pumpkin and pumpkin pie spice.  Sweet, but not too sweet with a bit of spicy bitterness in the end.  Medium bodied with a slightly lower than average carbonation leading to a short to medium pumpkin pie finish.  Truly one of the best pumpkin ales Ive had and its light enough in body to session.
never fails with schlafly to put out a good product.  spices really show through with this beer.

Bottle. Pours amber brown with a thin beigh head. Aroma of pumpkin pie, cinnamon, nutmeg and other fall spices. Flavor was pumpkin, strong cinnamon, nutmeg and subtle caramel with a slightly dry finish.

Overall a great seasonal I expected no less from Schafly. Typically when Ive had a poor release from them it is because the bottle has been sitting too long. This one was close to that point but still has some legs. I wouldnt sit on it much longer but it should be solid for at least another week or two.

Aroma / Appearance - A maroon red body a little darker than Santas suit the beer even had a white fringe. Thick and creamy it filled the glass well. Warm pumpkin pie with an emphasis on whipped cream created a sweet vegetal sensation. It was a bit more spicy and earthy than sweet though (like pumpkin ales at the other end of the spectrum).

Flavor / Palate - The chewy mouthfeel is like a mixture of 25% water and 75% pumpkin pie filling. Paired with sprinkles of nutmeg, a generous scoop of vanilla ice cream, and more holiday spices the combination is very seasonal. Straddling that line between something to drink several of and one to savor the beer has a nice balance. The rosy finish adds the feeling of stepping out of the cold into a warm hallway. I wouldnt mind having a six pack of this around October.

"I would rather sit on a pumpkin, and have it all to myself, than be crowded on a velvet cushion." 
- Henry David Thoreau.

From notes, 10/2008.

Pours a carrot orange, yet sits blood-red, almost velvet, in the glass. Nice lingering head. 

The smell on this one is poignant, in my opinion. As I sit here and type, I can smell the glass, eighteen inches from my nose. The cinnamon and nutmeg is strong and balanced by its malt profile. Great smelling pumpkin - complements fall nicely. In the mouth reigns cinnamon, then nutmeg, then a honey sweetness, then a light presence of ginger and cinnamon again. Excellent execution in both smell and taste.

More pleasing, full mouthfeel than I expected. Firm and velvety smooth. 

The 8.0% is hidden fantastically and, when fresh, this is killer. I have only had one pumpkin beer before this and it had quite a reputation. When I didnt like it, I swore off pumpkin ales for a short time, but couldnt resist this local offering. Come to find, weakness of will can be a good thing. EDIT: Since this review, I have had many pumpkin ales (TREAT, Pumpking, Weyerbachers) and this is still my favorite.

Bottle from Red Dog Wine & Spirits in Franklin, TN.
Smells of spices (cinnamon) and a little apple.
Pours a light caramel color, with very little head.
Taste does not quite live up to the aroma; a little dull. Thin mouthfeel.
Overall, a tad disappointing after the promising aroma and color. Im perhaps a little biased against pumpkin beers.

Tap, Patton Alley Pub, Springfield MO. Caramel pour, a bit of white head.  Pie spice nose and toffee sweetness, a bit of greenish pumpkin smell around the edges. Softly spicy sweet flavors, initially very pleasant, but gets pretty cloying after a few sips, and Traci and I had trouble finishing a pint between the two of us. For dessert, in a very small glass, might work.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper color with a thin off white head that leaves quickly and light lacing.  Strong aroma full of cinnamon, cloves, and pumpkin.  The spices are not as pronounced as they are in the aroma. Pumpkin is a flavor that comes through in the middle and finish of the beer. Cinnamon, clove, allspice and spicy ginger linger throughout.   Lighter mouthfeel with a subtle carbonation.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear amber color  with a medium sized quickly diminishing white head.  The aroma has a pleasing spice presence with an emphasis on nutmeg and cinnamon.  There is a nice sweetness that with the spices really reminds me of a warm pumpkin pie.   The flavor has all the characteristics from the nose with the inviting spiciness a sweet sugary maltiness, and a well integrated amount of pumpkin.  Medium mouth feel and very easy to drink.  This is one of the better pumpkin beers Ive had.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of pumpkin, spices, squash, nutmeg, light cinnamon, allspice, and slight ginger.  Poured orange in color with a small, off-white head that disappeared.  Slightly cloudy.  Slightly sparkling.  Full of tiny-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes much like it smells, of pumpkin, spices, cinnamon, light squash, nutmeg, allspice, and slight caramel.  Medium body.  Tingly, then lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Pumpkin, spice, cinnamon, and nutmeg finish is slightly dry.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Pours a beautiful vibrant orange with a white head.  Aroma was like spiced perfume.  Super aromatic but the aroma was overwhelming.  Cinnamon, nutmeg, a hint of pumpkin.  To perfumy.  Flavor was a bit cloying sweet, spiced, a little pumpkin.  Really just on the wrong edge of pumpkin beers.  THe flavor had potential but was cranked way to high.  Drain pour.

Bottle courtesy of drfabulous. Clear dark orange appearance with a bubbly white head. Aroma of lots of spice, cinnamon, floral soap, nutmeg. Some pumpkin I think? Flavor is lots of cinnamon with soapy overtones. Flavor of dry pumpkin falls on the finish.
Bottle from Cavie.  Deep amber pour with a small, off-white head.  Aroma is pumpkin pie, clove, and bread.  Taste is very cinnamon, malt, and caramel.  The cinnamon might be too much.
My other favorite pumpkin beer!  This one tastes more like pumpkin pie spice than like pumpkin.  An effervescent desert-like treat!

12 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA, opened 9/5/10. Pours a clear reddish amber color with a medium tan head that fades quickly. The aroma is pumpkin and big spice notes, including nutmeg, ginger and clove. The taste is pumpkin and fresh baked gingerbread. Cinnamon, nutmeg and other spices. Medium bodied. Damn good, and a contender for my favorite pumpkin ale ever. Nice job.

A: The pour is your rather average amber color with a fingers worth of off-white head.

S: Lots of pie spice notes fill the nose. I get plenty of cinnamon, nutmeg, and all spice. Theres a mild graham cracker malt note and rather than pumpkin, I get apples...

T: The apples are present on the flavor as well, but still not really any pumpkin qualities. The spices are the bulk of the flavors in this beer, and fit the same description as those mentioned in the aroma.

M: The body is medium with a fairly lively carbonation.

D: This didnt necessarily say "pumpkin beer" to me. It was much more of an apple pie beer, and a good one at that.

Ive never had a Pumpkin ale, so this will be my first time.  Poured into a dimpled mug.  First aroma and impression I get is of cinnamon, like a cinnamon red hot.  Caramel malt in the background as well.  The mall fizzy head quickly disappears.  First taste is  well, theres really no other way to describe this.  Its like drinking a liquid pumpkin pie, right down to the crust.  Clear pumpkin flavor up front followed by nutmeg, cinnamon, and clove.  Pie crust malt sweetness and powdered sugar finishes.  This thing is making me crave my moms pumpkin roll.  Im going to have to pick a lot of this up for Thanksgiving in November.  Delicious.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is deep amber with about an inch of off-white head on top; this quickly dissipates without a trace of lacing.  Nose is cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, sugar, pumpkin, and even the crust.  Taste is exactly the same, only it is pulled off without being overly sweet/syrupy with quite a light body.  Of all the pumpkin beers Ive tried, this one most closely mimics home made pumpkin pie on thanksgiving.  Definitely a treat that I could sip entirely too much of!  On a side note, where is the 8% ABV hidden?

Great deep amber coloured body with a bright orange glow when held up to a light and a lush, three centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of pumpkin pie spice, strong cinnamon, a bunch of hops (awesome to smell) and a bit of yeast. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong assertive malt, caramel, cinnamon, nutmeg and pumpkin are very noticeable throughout this. Chunky, chewy mouthful afterwards with a lot of sweetness, noticeable pumpkin and a good spicy character. Overall, a very nice and well done beer that shows a lot of complexity and pretty much everything youd want from a pumpkin beer. This one sits strong and deep, just like a meal - so if you want a beer thats almost like a meal or a bit to eat - drink this! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Bon Vivant Market in Smithfield, Virginia on 14-October-2010 for US$2.80 sampled at home in Washington on 21-October-2010.

Pronounced cinnamon and pumpkin aroma with clove accents. Clear orange, medium yellow head. Lots of cinnamon on the front end. Greater pumpkin notes appear later with nutmeg. Medium body. Much more cinnamon than most pumpkin spice beers. Exceptional for the style.

Pours a very dark amber color with no head. Smell is nutmeg and clover. Not getting all the cinnamon that was advertised, but still a decent nose. Taste is exactly the same as the nose. Taste has a acidic, bitterness taste to it. Medium body in the mouthfeel. This is a very sessionable beer, but at 8% it will definitely be felt.

Poured a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.  Aroma is of pumpkin pie and apple pie...lots of cinnamon on the nose.  Very sweet smelling.  Appearance is reddish brown with minimal head despite a vigorous pour.  The head leaves very quickly and looks like iced tea now.  Taste is better than expected, based on the aromas.  Pumpkin and squash flavors dominate, but the cinnamon overpowers up front.  The finish is medium, with gourd notes coming through.  Palate is thin to medium with little carbonation.  Overall one of the better pumpkin beers i have had...just not my favorite style.

Dark amber almost brown pour and clear with a creamy head. Nose is a cross between pumpkin and apple pie, nutmeg and sweet candy. Taste is similar, seriously just like a pumpkin pie. Really nice for a pumpkin beer. Strange and good.

Hazy cinnamon hue body with a very light head that withers quickly.  Aroma is heavy on the pumpkin spices of cinnamon, nutmeg, and some clove over a sweet, toasty, melanoidin-rich malt base.  Body is medium-full, with a malty texture, some breadiness, good spices, some pumpkin flavor, and both a bitter and carbonic bite from start to finish, slightly harsh and reminiscent of orange pith.  The bite "seems" to cloud some of the booziness, which is perceptible past the finish in a warm citric breathiness.  A good pumpkin ale, but clearly stronger spice on the nose than the tongue.  The spiky bitterness is also a bit off-putting and unexpected.  Still, with as strong an aroma as it has, it is sure to please.
Aroma is pumpkin pie, spices... Color is tan orange... Flavor is heavily spiced, nutmeg and cinnamon, cinnamon mainly dominates flavor... Pretty good, Ive had better, a little too much spice...

Amber color with minimal head and very little carbonation. Aroma is of nutmeg and cinnamon.  Flavor is also full of Fall spices. Nutmeg and cinnamon again with some over ripe fruit and alcohol. Some nice ginger bread and pumpkin pie.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2011 On tap at Galexy Hut in Arlington..  Dark Copper but the bar is dark too..  Slightly cloudy and no head or lacing .  sweet but to be expected and full of spices with just a little pumpkin, but much better that the dash of spices usually put in.  Some lighter fruits like pears in the first taste and dates later with a clean finish for something with this much suger.
10/2011 visited this mecca again
Amber color with white head.  Cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla aromas.  Malty flavor with cinnamon and nutmeg and pumpkin and vanilla.

12 oz goblet at the Schlafly Bottleworks in St Louis, Missouri. Pour is brown amber copper, slight haze, more or less no head. Aroma is spiced nutmeg, cinnamon, a touch of the pumpkin. Taste is pretty heavily spiced, nutmeg mostly, followed behind by pumpkin and a touch toasty malt. Certainly a pumpkin beer, perhaps more heavy handed than I prefer. It is very fresh and clean tasting. Palate is medium to heavy bodied, spritzy carbonation, spiced lingering aftertaste. Overall, really nice version of a style I am not usually crazy about.
Color is amberish, translucent, no head or lacing- looks like a flat watered-down cherry coke. Aroma is of carrot cake. Flavor is of carrot cake ice cream soup. 6 pack from Moon Wine and Spirits.

Aroma of caramelized sugar, honey-baked ham, brown sugar, maple, and of course pumpkin pie. Color is flat translucent deep amber, flavor is spicy and hot, pumpkin, butternut squash, not very vegetal. I think it could use a little aging to mellow out the alcohol. 6 pack from Moon Wine and Spirits.

Very nice version with a clear amber and small head. The aroma is autumn in moms kitchen with a roast chicken and pumpkin pie. The flavor is similar with the spices not overpowering. It has a nice bit of burn to it. Nice on those cool Fall nights.

I like this one a bit sweet at first but leaving it in the fridge for a couple of weeks has mellowed it out very well.  Medium bodied with little to no head on the pour, but has a nice crisp mouth feel for a pumpkin beer.  I can smell  nutmeg, cloves, orange peel, raisins, and slight pumpkin pie in there as well.  I can taste the pumpkin first and foremost mixing in with the cinnamon and nutmeg.  I can also taste slight ginger and cloves mixing in as well.  Great beer I highly recommend it.

12 oz bottle from Whole Foods. Pours a deep amber brown with no head. Initial aroma is not pleasant-very metallic. Eases as it warms to reveal a light sweetness over the spice, dominated by clove. Bit of zip, presumably from the cinnamon. Taste is spice up front, then yielding to an unpleasant off aftertaste. Just seems like this beer hasnt come together yet (label notes a bottling of Aug 24, 2010). Overly carbonated and thin. Not going down easy. Not great. While I love the arrival of all the pumpkin and autumn beers, they just rarely seem to live up to the excitement. Pass.

pours a nice autumn maple with small head. aroma is all spice and pumpkin pie with a hint of clove. mouthful starts out nice and pumpkin pie like then is dominated by clove. there is room for improvement by simple backing of the clove thing..
Very nice color - deep amber. Aroma is full of sweet pumpkin, spice and malts. Flavor is quite chewey, good and pumpkin, but perhaps a tad bit too sweet. Spices are wonderful though.
Draft at KC F.S. Very spicy, in a good way. Relatively thin body overall. Tastes like pumpkin bread more than pumpkin pie if youre looking for something to compare it to. Alcohol is buried away.

Small white head with fair retention and minimal lace. Clear orange/copper hued brew. Nose is yer basic pumpkin beer nose, nutmeg, cinnamon, etc,  with a little malt coming through. Light bodied, little sticky, soft carbonation. Not overly done spiceyness, a bit sweet (for me) and sticky, faint mlats and gourdy notes hiding in there. Lightly sweet finish. Meh. 6r procured @statelineliquors.

Bottle from SL. Poured with a red-amber color, decent initial sized head. The aroma was spices and pumkin as expected. The flavor actually featured the pumpkin with the spices not overwhelming this thing. It also wasnt sweet or cloying, probably a little light in flavor and body overall, finishing somewhat dry. A decent pumpkin ale.

Bottle picked up at SL, thanks to matt for the rec. Pours a red color, with out much head.... Smells decent, light pumpkin, spices, nutmeg and cinnamon. Nice pumpkin beer... not sweet or overly spiced.. Strong pumpkin notes with cinnamon and spices in the background, a little warming from the alcohol. Medium body... Nice pumkin beer, very enjoyable

Bottle. Dark amber pour with a short white head. Strong cinnamon and nutmeg in the nose. Light clove and pumpkin pie as well. Taste is sweet with more cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin pie and candied yams. Body is light-medium with a strong, bubbly carbonation. Finishes with more sweet notes, pumpkin pie and cinnamon. Tasty!
Bottle. Pours brown with an off-white head. Flavor is straight pumpkin pie.. cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin pie mix, and crust. Very good.

355mL courtesy of tastybeer. Poured a clear deep ruby red with a massive tan head. Good retention. No lace. Huge pumpkin pie nose and taste. Rich. Eventually becomes a clear red syrup with no head. Nose is strawberry candy, some fall spices, big nutmeg, gingerbread. Taste is spot on: sweet, rich, creamy pumpkin pie, lots of spices. Full bodied and spot on for pumpkin beer.

Dark Amber like Arizona clay...wirey, cream colored head. Medium bodied, slightly flat, spices liven it up a tad.

Nose: Heavy on spices, more nutmeg than cinnamon. Light showing of true, not sweet, pumpkin.
Taste: Pumpkin, then NUTMEG, then pumpkin. A true pumpkin, not in the pumpkin pie family.The nutmeg is totalitarian.
Smells very sweet, of pumpkin, cinnamon, and other spices.  Great appearance.  Pretty carbonated, thin head, tastes OK.
Clear orangish brown pour with small brown head. Aroma is cinnamon, pumpkin spice, nutmeg, bread. Flavor is pumpkin bread, clove, pumpkin spice. Tasty!

Draught at Churchkey.  Clear brown, no head, no lacing.  Aroma is subtle spice.  Taste is chewy, warm pumpkin pie with a dollop of cream on top.  Not usually my thing, but this is one of the best tasting pumpkin beers I have ever had.

Only sampled from a 12oz. bottle. Poured a clear, dark copper color, small white head. Aroma is spice: nutmeg, cinnamon. Also smelled a bready, almost like pie crust. Flavor was a bit sweet, relatively balanced. Alcohol is well hidden.

Honey/amber with a beige head. Strong spicy aromas of nutmeg and cinnamon.Flavor was sweet, caramel malts, caramel sugar, fall spices. Warm and soft with a sneaky strong alcoholic finish. Lots of pumpkin, spice and sweetness-all it needs is some Cool Whip.

This brew appears in the local supermarkets (Schnucks, and Dierbergs) around the last week in August. They run out in early November, if they can stay on the shelves that long. Ive mailed this brew to friends across the country; it is a hit all around. If you like pumpkin pie, then youll enjoy this, as it has almost the same sweet taste. Get ready to taste the best pumkin beer ever!

Pours brownish orange amber with an off white head.   Aroma is caramel, pumpkin, nutmeg, clove and cinnamon.  Flavor is full of pumpkin pie spice and flavor, with great hints of pumpkin and squash.  Great fall brew.

Pours dark clear amber with some particles and a small off-white head. Aroma of pumpkin, caramel and bold spice. taste is a milder sweetness with some bitter roast  and mild spice. Medium thin body, lively carbonation.
Pours a lasting ring of off-white head with a copper-brown body.  Aromas of caramel, dough, and spices.  Flavor is fruity, dough, cinnamon, nutmeg.  Finish is pumpkin pie and alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2010 12 oz. bottle.  Pours a rich red-amber color with a small off-white head.  Holy smokes, this smells more like pumpkin pie than any pumpkin beer Ive ever had: nutmeg, cinnamon, brown sugar, vanilla, cream, clove.  The flavor isnt as exciting, and starts a lot like the nose but then flattens out over the course of the drink.  Nutmeg and clove are strong on the palate, with caramel malts and floral and cinnamon notes.  Light-medium bodied, with some carbonation and a somewhat watery palate.  Good take on a pumpkin beer.  RE-RATE: This one is going up a few notches after trying it last night at the Bottleworks.  I was fortunate enough to get it on the first day it was tapped this season, and its tasting awesome fresh.  Caramel, nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, squash/pumpkin, brown sugar, and vegetal notes that seem to complement the flavors.  Man oh man, this is excellent.  It looks great in the snifter, a rich, dark amber color.  Kudos to Schalfly on making one of the best pumpkin ales youll find and not just making a gimmicky seasonal that sells well (though it does).

Pours a golden orange with very little head and no retention. Aroma is spicy, definitely smell the cinnamon and the pumpkin, also can smell some vegetable undertones, for some reason zuchinni pops at me. Taste is spicy with the same cinnamon and pumpkin. I think since they call it a pumpkin Ale, they are hitting the nail on the head. Good for once, not sure id be looking forward to it all year.

Vegetal spicy pie aroma. More actual pumpkin. Golden light amber thin foam. Pumpkin meat, spicy cinnamon - lots of it. Interesting mix, lots of spice - black pepper and menthol mouth feel. Nice use of spice.

12oz bottle from suzygreenberg.  Clear orange amber with small white head.  Light spice on the nose but mostly big purée pumpkin an some white bread toast aroma.  Flavor is more on the vegital pumpkin side with spice making an apperance but missing a bit in either the body or rounding out of the overall flavor.  Dont get me wrong though, this is better than what I can get locally, but the Willamsburg is killer!

12 oz. bottle - dark copper, clear, slight fog white head; lots of spice, nutmeg, cinnamon; light texture is smooth with mild spice and pumpkin pie crust flavor; easily top by the Williamsburg version; dry, sweet and smooth; good stuff

Golden amber tinted copper color with a slight haze. Good, full head of foam. Minimal retention and lacing.

Cinnamon and nutmeg mingle with allspice and a slight scent of pumpkin. Good malty notes here.

This ones a keeper!
Very nice pumpkin flavor mixes with the cinnamon and nutmeg. Good malty backbone. Sweet, yet spicey. Good balance.

Nice and creamy mouthfeel. Good medium body, like this style should be, IMO. Great carbonation level, almost perfect.

Very drinkable. Id love to have access to this on a regular basis.

This beer is a clear copper-orange color with a medium thin off-white head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Nutmeg, ginger and cinnamon aroma. Medium body with flavors of pumpkin, malt, ginger and other spices. The finish is all pumpkin pie flavors. Overall a tasty pumpkin beer.

Scored this as an extra via trade.  Let it be known, I am very skeptical of pumpkin beers.  12oz bottle pours a transparent orange, amber with a wispy white head that faded quick.  Cold, the aroma was of raw pumpkin.  Once it warmed up the spice came through the nose, nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, with a hint of alcohol.  Flavor was sweet, caramel malts, caramel sugar, squash, spices.  Finish is sticky.  All in all, a pretty good pumpkin beer.  Very drinkable.

12oz bottle.  Pours a lightly hazed faint copper color with a frothy off white head, light lacing.  Nose holds some nice pumpkin and clove spice with some nutmeg and cinnamon in there as well.  Mostly cinnamon and nutmeg on the palate, finish is very creamy.....good stuff!

12oz bottle from Woodys in Franklin, TN. Pours burnt orange, thin white head and lots of carbonation. Beautiful aroma of pumpkin pie, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Im a sucker for anything pumpkin...there is tons of spicy pumpkin pie flavor here...it would be amazing if not for an offputting metallic aftertaste. The mouthfeel is very nice: medium, warm, and a bit sticky. Overall i like it. And i love pumpkin!

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep amber brown with a huge creamy light tan head. Aroma is gigantic spice. Much more on the spice side than the pumpkin side which I can appreciate. Lots of ginger, cinnamon, clove and nutmeg, a smörgåsbord of holiday spice. Almost dusty in the way it pinches the nostrils. Flavor is much more rounded. Lots of sweet pumpkin mixed with the spices and making for a big pumpkin pie and spiced bread flavor.   The spices in the nose especially help balanced the sweetness giving it a really nice dessert taste. Medium to full body and a soft carbonation. Really nice pumpkin beer

12oz bottle (Bottled with Love on 09 15 2009) served in a shaker.  Dark amber pour with a light haze and a thin cap of tan foam.  Minimal lacing.  The aroma had strong notes of gingerbread and pie spices, also some sweet caramel.  Sweet and malty.  The flavor was like a gingerbread cookie.  A nice mix of cinnamon, nutmeg, and caramel.  Surprised that this is 8%.  Full-bodied and softly carbonated.  The spices run the show in this beer, but it isnt cloying or annoying.  I like it.

Bottle. Poured an amber orange with a darkish off-white head. Aroma was full of pumpkin pie notes with lots of cinnamon, nutmeg and ginger accompanying the pumpkin. Flavor mirrors the aroma beautifully. A nice medium mouthfeel makes this by far my favorite pumpkin beer.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark amber little bubbly head. Pumpkin cinnamon and vanilla aroma. Great pumpkin flavor with an intense cinnamon. Nice carb. Makes me want to put whip cream on it.

Pours amber with a mostly receding off-white head. Aroma of nutmeg, cinnamon, toffee. Taste is spicy, phenolic, toffee, gingerbread, nutmeg, and cinaamon. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation. Not bad, but pretty spice centric.

Pours a brilliant red hued amber.  Strong aroma of nutmeg, clove, cinnamon.  Very spicy and aromatic nose.  Initial taste is full of spice.  Clove comes through.  Nutmeg and cinnamon are more abundant in the finish.  Quite spicy and good. Enjoy on a crisp cool evening.
Probably the best pumpkin beer Ive had thus far this season. Not overly sweet or spicy. Seems to just have the right mix to be very, very drinkable.

Has an amber color with a medium off-white head that dissipates quickly.  It has a delicious aroma of pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon, and a hint of ginger.  The taste starts sweet and slowly gets bigger with malty nutmeg finish.
Pours a coppery brown with a small off white head. Aroma of pumpkin pie spice. Flavor is cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and a little pumpkin. One of my favorite pumpkin beers.

Being a huge fan of pumpkin ale, this one really got me excited. Pumpkin is there in full but not overwhelming and the spices are just right. This and weyerbacher imperial pumpkin are my top choices for pumpkin ale

Bottle from beastiefan2k - thanks Eugene!  Reddish orange with mega floaties and a thin tan quickly fading topper.  Aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, pumpkin, ah pumpkin pie.  Taste of nutmeg, cinnamon, pumpkin with no real hop presence.  Finishes up very dry.  The beer that ushered in the Kurt Phillips era for the Badgers, lets hope its a winning one.

bottle, tanks beastiefan, pours a blood orange color with a thin white head.  The aroma is wonderful.  Pumpkin pie all the way, pumpkin, spice and cinnamon.  Light body with a toasted malt character but the flavors are all pumpkin pie again.  Lots of pumpkin, spice and sweetness.  Lingering spice in the finish.  I like this one.

Bottled with love on 8/21/2009 - FRESH!  Just appeared in Kansas City, and boy am I glad.

Pours a clear, rich copper color with a perfect off-white head.  Third pumpkin in 2 hours...either theyre growing on me, or I put them in the right order!  Aroma is a crazy explosion of nutmeg with some cinnamon, pumpkin pie, and a bit of anise/licorice.

Flavor is just a touch strong on the cinnamon and allspice, drowning out the obvious pumpkin undertones.  Unlike the OFallon, this one really tastes like pumpkin, not pumpkin pie mix and evaporated milk.  Medium body, medium carbonation, dry, spicy finish.  Honestly, could have been close to a 4 if only a little less bold.

Bottle. One of the pumpkins that really gets it right, truly pie-like with all the appropriate spices. Pretty sweet from the fairly sizable malt, but appropriately so, dessert-like despite all the spices, quite rich.
One of the better pumplin beers I have had. Even with some age on it. Great spices with some pumpkin flesh too. Nice sweet balance with brown sugar to go with the pie spices. Nice.

Bottle at PPRBSG 09.  Pours a mostly clear filtered look with a filmy white head.  Aroma is typical all spice, pumpkin character, clovey and cinnamon, nutmeg, etc with light caramel malts, hints of toffee, and metallic copper hints.  Ok pumpkin flavor, sweet, orangey caramel, toasted malts, fruity esters, allspice, and hints of pine and pumpkin pie.  Ok.

Bottle at PilsnerPeters Spring Gathering.  Pours a clear orange with a thin white head.  Aromas of clove and cinnamon and light pumpkin spice.  Flavor follows the nose mostly, ending with a crisp light bitterness.

Bottle at PPRBSG09.  Pours a clear orange.  Aroma of sweet pumpkin pie.  Some crust too, but mostly pie.  Flavor of cinnamon, sweet crust, and lots of pumpkin spices.  Quite good (especially considering its out of season).  One of my favorite pumpkin beers.
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2009 PPRBSG.  Pours a brown body with a tan head.  Pumpkin pie and vanilla and cinnamon clove notes.  Very nice pumpkin brew doesnt taste artificial at all. 

Had this on draft in KC, i rated it 3.8-9, so i will just leave this rating.  Good stuff.  Actually i think Eugene brought the bottle i rated at Peters Gathering.

12 oz. bottle via trade with beastiefan2k - Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a thin off white head.  Aroma is spicy, but not much pumpkin.  Again, flavor is spice and light pumpkin.  Medium body.  Its no Southern Tier Pumpkin, but its not bad.  Thanks Eugene.

Bottle. This definitely isnt my favorite style at all. However, I decided to grab a 6 of these. For a pumpkin beer, not bad at all. One of the better pumpkin beers I have ever tried. Pours a hazy orange color with no head. Aroma is pumpkin, nutmeg, spice, and cinnamon. Taste is all the same. Almost too much pumpkin flavor though, couldnt really taste the other flavors. Decent beer though.

courtesy of tilley4
This one belongs up there with the best of pumpkin beers, and certainly is in my top 5 for the pumpkin style.
Pours copper - orange with white head.
Aroma is of course of pumpkin with a blend of other spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, clove) with light caramel. Overall everything, it left a nice sweet nose.
Taste, not flooded with pumpkin but really well balanced with the other spices so none really come more across than the other. The mouthfeel was amazing with a light dough / butter cream palate enhanced by the spices, mostly cinnamon.
Medium carbonation with nice tingly palate and a warming after taste.

Bottle received via trade with Mr. Rain (thanks!).  Poured amber/orange with a little bit of carbonation.  Aroma is excellent, nutmeg, clove, pepper and of course a little pumpkin as well.  Flavor also well done, rich and thick mouthfeel and almost like taking a bite of fresh pie.  This is probably the closest pumpkin beer Ive had that could pass for the true flavor of pumpkin pie.  Give this one a try if you can get it.

Thanks to beastiefan2k!

Rating from memory, unfortunately cant find my notes on it

Aroma  fantastic, pumpkin, spices, beer 
Pours orange amber, good 

Taste  so good!  Great beer + pumpkin pie = glory

Mouthfeel  rich and smooth

Overall, this is the best pumpkin beer Ive had.

Bottle courtesy of Beastiefan2k poured a clear dark orange with a lingering ring of light amber foam. Aromas of cinnamon, nutmeg, light carmel and light pumpkin. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of cinnamon, nutmeg, brown sugar and a hint of pumpkin with a smooth spiced finish.

12oz. bottle, with thanks to Gregis.  Pours a clear golden orange, with a quickly dissipating tan head, minimal retention and lacing. Aroma is pumpkin, cinnamon, and allspice. Flavor is more of the same, with more sweetness. Interesting, but lacking more dimension than I’d hope, although not surprising since its a Pumpkin. Decent for the style, but finding I’m not a huge fan of this genre. Thanks Greg!

One of the best pumpkins I’ve tested.  You can nicely taste the pumpkin; not mild but not overpowering or too sweet.  Nice overall brew.  The only other pumpkin that I’ve found similar is Weyerbacher.
